Building AI systems that work? It's not just about the technology. It's about governance at every layer.

Anuj Krishna, Cofounder and President, MathCo, breaks down the four critical governance questions organizations must answer:

Context: What does a central group own? How do business groups collaborate? How do feedback loops work?

Agents: How do you use existing agents? What needs to be built? Who owns what?

Orchestration: Who owns the framework? What kinds are needed? How do you apply it in business?

Interface: How do you design with users and personas in mind to make it real for them?

Each layer needs its own roadmap, governance model, and clear ownership. Or your AI system won't scale.

Watch the full breakdown from MachineCon 2025!

AIM

We recently brought together industry analysts and ecosystem partners at MathCo's Intelligence Hub in Bengaluru for a full-day event dedicated to exploring the state and future of enterprise AI transformation.
 
The reality is concerning: 88% of AI proof-of-concepts don't scale to enterprise-wide deployment, and only 25% of AI initiatives deliver expected ROI.

Charlie Madison began playing piano at six, encouraged by his parents, who hoped music might offer him a gentle focus and a new way to engage with his surroundings. â€œI was always told that rhythm and melody could help my senses connect,â€ he shares. Those early lessons were more than just notesâ€”they were a lifeline, a way to find comfort and confidence.

As Charlie grew, his relationship with the piano shifted. â€œAt night, after my family fell asleep, Iâ€™d play and sing songs from my favorite singer-songwriters,â€ he remembers. While he practiced classical pieces during the day, those nightly sessions were different. â€œExpressing myself musically felt like a secret, a safe space away from the pressures of being the nerdy kid in a sports-focused town.â€ The piano became his refuge, allowing him to find his own voice at a time when he felt like an outlier.

Charlie credits the piano with teaching him the value of patience and consistent effort. â€œRepetition, repetition, repetitionâ€”that stuck with me, whether Iâ€™m practicing a piece or debugging a tough line of code. Artistry comes from showing up and working through the details.â€ Heâ€™s carried that mindset into his work at MathCo, taking pride in his focus and high standards, while also learning to embrace progress over perfection. â€œIn live performances, even if you make a mistake, you keep going. Most people wonâ€™t notice, and stopping just breaks the spell.â€

For Charlie, music has always been about communityâ€”memories of high school musicals, singing telegrams with friends, and small moments of validation, like the coffee shop owner who once wrote,â€œ Itâ€™s clear you have a lot of poetry and music in you.â€ Those words still mean the world.

And for anyone looking to learn piano as an adult, Charlie offers this advice: â€œIf you want to play a few favorites, have fun! But if you want to learn truly, donâ€™t skip the basics. Theyâ€™re the key to unlocking everything music has to offer.â€ His journey is proof that patience and a love of the process can open doorsâ€”at the piano and beyond.

This World Photography Day, we celebrate how a simple passion can transform the way we see the world. For Chethan R, it began quietly in his backyard, photographing cats with a basic point-and-shoot camera.

But it was the visit to Kabini and the BRT Tiger Reserve that changed everything. "Something about watching animals in their natural habitat just clicked. I realized this wasn't just a hobby anymoreâ€”it was something deeper", he reminisces.

One of his most treasured captures features a leopardess at the Bhadra Tiger Reserve. "She had just woken up from a nap and was giving us all these poses. But when she yawned, that was pure magic." Such moments make the long waits worthwhile. "I've done over 100 safaris in tiger reserves and only seen tigers a couple of times. But when it happens, it's everything."

Wildlife photography outings are anything but predictable. "I've spent three hours in a forest without seeing a single bird or animal," he admits. "But that's part of the process. You do your research on animal behaviour and weather patterns, then you wait." He recalls waiting for a serpent eagle to retrieve its dropped kill, a Russell's viper snake. "We never got the shot, but the experience itself was incredible."

For those intimidated by wildlife photography, his advice is simple: "Start in your backyard. Photograph birds, squirrels, even insects. You don't need to fly to the Masai Mara right away", he quips.

The unpredictability that makes wildlife photography challenging is also what makes it beautiful. "Weather changes in an instant, animals don't perform on cue, and opportunities vanish in seconds. But sometimes that 'failed' outing leads to something even better", he reflects.

Chethan's journey proves that exceptional shots come from showing up consistently with patience and respect. Wildlife photography mirrors life itselfâ€”unpredictable, humbling, and ultimately rewarding.

For Venkatraman G S, Chief Financial Officer at MathCo, every step in his corporate journey has been thought throughâ€”taking on challenges, driven by learning, discipline, and the belief that doing what's right for the organization matters more than convenience.

"If I had to sum up my journey in finance, it's been a fantastic one of constant learning, taking on roles that required me to acquire new skills, helping me set up and run multiple functions within Finance and Risk Management, building great teams, and growing as a finance professional."

"The journey evolved from doing Branch Accounting manually to being part of ERP rollouts, using technology to get real-time financial reports as a CFO for fast-growing companies. Working with inspiring leaders, observing them, and learning what makes them successful."

Taking on unfamiliar roles became a pattern, each pushing Venky to adapt and grow.

"As I stepped into roles I'd never done beforeâ€”front-ending client reviews, setting up business finance, or leading Enterprise Risk Managementâ€”I realized growth doesn't come from having all the answers. It comes from asking the right questions, preparing well, and surrounding yourself with people you can learn from."

On what excites him most about MathCo, Venky says, "I see a younger, high-energy team solving high-growth problems, not just optimization ones. I'm excited to work with leadership to enable MathCo's continued fast-paced growth, both organic and inorganic."

"As we grow, it would be interesting to use some analytics and forecasting models we offer clients within finance. That's when it gets real: when belief in your product powers your own decisions."

When it comes to leading teams, he believes in clarity, fairness, and immediate feedback. "Be direct, be fair, and always offer feedback that helps people grow. Don't wait for reviews; give real-time input to build consistency and trust."

His advice to young finance professionals? Go beyond numbers.
"Knowing your function isn't enough. Understand your business, the customers you serve, the issues you help solve, and how your work fits the larger value chain. You're not 'just' doing reporting or payroll; you enable the business to succeed."

He sees the CFO role evolving fast, working closely with CEOs to enable growth and strategy, not just manage financials. "Technology is transforming how we work, and we must stay ahead. Finance teams must collaborate with engineers, product teams, and data scientists."

Looking ahead, Venky is energized by MathCo's momentum. "It's been a great start. We're solving good problems. I'm here to help scale the company, strengthen governance, and support leadership as we build the next phase of growth."

For Venky, one thing holds true: "Success isn't about getting everything right, it's about getting better every day and doing what's right for the organization, not what's convenient."

"I pursued my MSW with a specialization in Human Resources, and that's where it all started," says Isaac A, Talent Acquisition Associate at MathCo.
 
"Through my academic journey, I explored both the worlds of social work and corporate HR. Interning in both spaces gave me a deep understanding of how empathy and execution go hand in hand when you're working with people."
 
"I knew I wanted to be part of a company that valued both learning and people-oriented, yet open to fresh ideas. That's when I found MathCo."
 
Starting his career here as a fresher in Talent Acquisition, Isaac describes the experience as fast-paced, dynamic, and incredibly rewarding.
 
"People often think TA is all about sourcing and numbers, but it's much more than that. It's about understanding where talent fits, communicating across stakeholders, and, most importantly, creating meaningful candidate experiences."
 
He shares how MathCo's flat hierarchy helped him feel included from day one. "Even as a fresher, I got to interact with leaders, understand business goals, and contribute in real ways. There's space here to speak up, learn continuously, and grow through every challenge."
 
"What I value most is the support system, the mentors who guide you, the team that always has your back, and the belief that your work matters, no matter your designation."
 
Looking back, Isaac says, "MathCo gave me the foundation, exposure, and confidence to build a meaningful career in HR."
From learning the ropes to making a real impact, this is just the beginning of Isaac's journey.

"I received my undergraduate degree in English from Penn State and thought my career would be in journalism or copywriting," says Catherine Laborde, Head of Human Resources and Operations at MathCo. "It wasn't until someone I worked for said, 'Have you considered working in HR? You could turn it on its head with your people skills, conversational style, and analytical brain.' That one comment opened a door I hadn't considered."

Catherine began her HR journey nearly 15 years ago at a large specialty food store in Philadelphia, supporting a bustling catering business and shipping warehouse.

"My office was directly above the store, which gave me an up-close view of the people's experience," they recall. "I dove into hiring, problem-solving, and day-to-day support. It was HR in its most hands-on, human form".

Since then, they've built a career that spans marketing and advertising, architecture and engineering, and tech sales, always with a people-first mindset. Prior to joining MathCo, they held leadership roles and worked in a global capacity, overseeing the US, Canada, EU, UK, and APAC region, which made MathCo's international team especially appealing.

"What drew me in was the opportunity to continue working on a global scale, but with a team that truly values empathy and intelligence in equal measure.

"Now at MathCo, I oversee Recruiting, Talent, Learning & Development, the overall people experience, and operational people support," they explain. "We're growing quickly, so a big part of my role involves strategic planning and change management, but I never hesitate to roll up my sleeves and get tactical. I love being at work with my team, mentoring them, and seeing them grow and learn."

What keeps them energized? Creating a culture where people feel safe to bring their whole, authentic selves to work daily.

"One of the most rewarding parts of my job is watching people grow through the organization. Seeing someone step into their potential is what drives me. MathCo has been my home for three years, and being part of its growth story feels like a privilege."

"I did my MBA in Marketing and HR and started my career as a management trainee." says Aparna Nirmalan, Content Associate at MathCo. 
 
"During that time, I realized my strengths lay in marketing communications. I naturally gravitated towards comms and thought leadership projects, and just as I was looking to move into internal communications and talent branding, I came across the opportunity at MathCo."
 
"Even though it's only been a year here, the learning has been immense." What stands out most for Aparna is the trust and belief the team places in her.
 
"That belief has helped me believe in myself more," she shares. "I've been encouraged to take on tougher, more challenging projects, and that's pushed me to grow faster than I expected."
 
"The team works as one. There's no 'your work' or 'my work'; it's always 'our work.' If someone can't manage something, someone else steps in without hesitation."
 
"It's incredibly empowering," she adds.
 
She reflects on how exposure to diverse perspectives has reshaped her thinkingâ€”encouraging her to question, innovate, and explore bold ideas.

"People often think comms is just sending emails, but there's so much more to it. It's about message design, clarity, timing, what turns a message into something people actually connect with, especially in today's world where everyone's bombarded with information."
 
Working closely with senior leaders and being part of cross-functional projects has given her a holistic view of communication and valuable stakeholder management experience.
 
"There's also space to fail and figure things out. That freedom to experiment is a huge confidence booster. I've grown as a communicator, yes, but I've also grown as a professional who's learning to think bigger and push harder."

We recently brought together industry analysts and ecosystem partners at MathCo's Intelligence Hub in Bengaluru for a full-day event dedicated to exploring the state and future of enterprise AI transformation.

The reality is concerning: 88% of AI proof-of-concepts don't scale to enterprise-wide deployment, and only 25% of AI initiatives deliver expected ROI.

Companies invest heavily in experimentation, only to see initiatives remain isolated, fail to integrate with core processes, or struggle to demonstrate sustained value. Charlie Madison began playing piano at six, encouraged by his parents, who hoped music might offer him a gentle focus and a new way to engage with his surroundings. â€œI was always told that rhythm and melody could help my senses connect,â€ he shares. Those early lessons were more than just notesâ€”they were a lifeline, a way to find comfort and confidence.

As Charlie grew, his relationship with the piano shifted. â€œAt night, after my family fell asleep, Iâ€™d play and sing songs from my favorite singer-songwriters,â€ he remembers. While he practiced classical pieces during the day, those nightly sessions were different. â€œExpressing myself musically felt like a secret, a safe space away from the pressures of being the nerdy kid in a sports-focused town.â€ The piano became his refuge, allowing him to find his own voice at a time when he felt like an outlier.

Charlie credits the piano with teaching him the value of patience and consistent effort. â€œRepetition, repetition, repetitionâ€”that stuck with me, whether Iâ€™m practicing a piece or debugging a tough line of code. Artistry comes from showing up and working through the details.â€ Heâ€™s carried that mindset into his work at MathCo, taking pride in his focus and high standards, while also learning to embrace progress over perfection. â€œIn live performances, even if you make a mistake, you keep going. Most people wonâ€™t notice, and stopping just breaks the spell.â€

For Charlie, music has always been about communityâ€”memories of high school musicals, singing telegrams with friends, and small moments of validation, like the coffee shop owner who once wrote,â€œ Itâ€™s clear you have a lot of poetry and music in you.â€ Those words still mean the world.

And for anyone looking to learn piano as an adult, Charlie offers this advice: â€œIf you want to play a few favorites, have fun! But if you want to learn truly, donâ€™t skip the basics. Theyâ€™re the key to unlocking everything music has to offer.â€ His journey is proof that patience and a love of the process can open doorsâ€”at the piano and beyond.

This World Photography Day, we celebrate how a simple passion can transform the way we see the world. For Chethan, it began quietly in his backyard, photographing cats with a basic point-and-shoot camera.

But it was the visit to Kabini and the BRT Tiger Reserve that changed everything. â€œSomething about watching animals in their natural habitat just clicked. I realized this wasnâ€™t just a hobby anymoreâ€”it was something deeperâ€, he reminisces.

One of his most treasured captures features a leopardess at the Bhadra Tiger Reserve. â€œShe had just woken up from a nap and was giving us all these poses. But when she yawned, that was pure magic.â€ Such moments make the long waits worthwhile. â€œIâ€™ve done over 100 safaris in tiger reserves and only seen tigers a couple of times. But when it happens, itâ€™s everything.â€

Wildlife photography outings are anything but predictable. â€œIâ€™ve spent three hours in a forest without seeing a single bird or animal,â€ he admits. â€œBut thatâ€™s part of the process. You do your research on animal behaviour and weather patterns, then you wait.â€ He recalls waiting for a serpent eagle to retrieve its dropped kill, a Russellâ€™s viper snake. â€œWe never got the shot, but the experience itself was incredible.â€
For those intimidated by wildlife photography, his advice is simple: â€œStart in your backyard. Photograph birds, squirrels, even insects. You donâ€™t need to fly to the Masai Mara right awayâ€, he quips.

The unpredictability that makes wildlife photography challenging is also what makes it beautiful. â€œWeather changes in an instant, animals donâ€™t perform on cue, and opportunities vanish in seconds. But sometimes that â€˜failedâ€™ outing leads to something even betterâ€, he reflects.

Chethanâ€™s journey proves that exceptional shots come from showing up consistently with patience and respect. Wildlife photography mirrors life itselfâ€”unpredictable, humbling, and ultimately rewarding.

For Venkatraman G S, CFO at MathCo, every step in his journey has been intentionalâ€”taking on challenges, driven by learning, discipline, and the belief that doing what's right matters more than convenience.

"If I had to sum up my journey in finance, it's been one of constant learning, taking on roles that required new skills, helping me set up and run multiple functions within Finance and Risk Management, building great teams, and growing as a finance professional."

From manually performing Branch Accounting to ERP rollouts to using technology for real-time reporting as CFO for fast-growing companies, Venky learned from inspiring leaders by observing what made them successful.

"As I stepped into roles I'd never done beforeâ€”front-ending client reviews, setting up business finance, or leading Enterprise Risk Managementâ€”I realized growth doesn't come from having all the answers. It comes from asking the right questions, preparing well, and surrounding yourself with people you can learn from."

On MathCo, he says, "I see a younger, high-energy team solving high-growth problems, not just optimization ones. I'm excited to work with leadership to enable MathCo's fast-paced growth, both organic and inorganic." When leading teams, his belief is clear: "Be direct, be fair, and always offer feedback that helps people grow. Don't wait for reviews; give real-time input to build consistency and trust."

His advice to young finance professionals? "Knowing your function isn't enough. Understand your business, the customers you serve, the issues you help solve, and how your work fits the larger value chain."

He sees CFOs closely partnering with CEOs. "Technology is transforming how we work, and we must stay ahead. Finance teams must collaborate with engineers, product teams, and data scientists." Looking ahead, Venky says, I'm here to help scale the company, strengthen governance, and support leadership as we build the next phase of growth."

For him, one truth stands: "Success isn't about getting everything right, it's about getting better every day and doing what's right for the organization, not what's convenient."

"I received my undergraduate degree in English from Penn State and thought my career would be in journalism or copywriting," says Catherine Laborde, Head of Human Resources and Operations at MathCo. "It wasn't until someone I worked for said, 'Have you considered working in HR? You could turn it on its head with your people skills, conversational style, and analytical brain.' That one comment opened a door I hadn't considered."

Catherine began her HR journey nearly 15 years ago at a large specialty food store in Philadelphia, supporting a bustling catering business and shipping warehouse.

"My office was directly above the store, which gave me an up-close view of the people's experience," they recall. "I dove into hiring, problem-solving, and day-to-day support. It was HR in its most hands-on, human form".

Since then, they've built a career that spans marketing and advertising, architecture and engineering, and tech sales, always with a people-first mindset. Prior to joining MathCo, they held leadership roles and worked in a global capacity, overseeing the US, Canada, EU, UK, and APAC region, which made MathCo's international team especially appealing.

"What drew me in was the opportunity to continue working on a global scale, but with a team that truly values empathy and intelligence in equal measure.

"Now at MathCo, I oversee Recruiting, Talent, Learning & Development, the overall people experience, and operational people support," they explain. "We're growing quickly, so a big part of my role involves strategic planning and change management, but I never hesitate to roll up my sleeves and get tactical. I love being at work with my team, mentoring them, and seeing them grow and learn."

What keeps them energized? Creating a culture where people feel safe to bring their whole, authentic selves to work daily.

"One of the most rewarding parts of my job is watching people grow through the organization. Seeing someone step into their potential is what drives me. MathCo has been my home for three years, and being part of its growth story feels like a privilege."

"I did my MBA in Marketing and HR and started my career as a management trainee." says Aparna Nirmalan, Content Associate at MathCo. 
 
"During that time, I realized my strengths lay in marketing communications. I naturally gravitated towards comms and thought leadership projects, and just as I was looking to move into internal communications and talent branding, I came across the opportunity at MathCo."
 
"Even though it's only been a year here, the learning has been immense." What stands out most for Aparna is the trust and belief the team places in her.
 
"That belief has helped me believe in myself more," she shares. "I've been encouraged to take on tougher, more challenging projects, and that's pushed me to grow faster than I expected."
 
"The team works as one. There's no 'your work' or 'my work'; it's always 'our work.' If someone can't manage something, someone else steps in without hesitation."
 
"It's incredibly empowering," she adds.
 She reflects on how exposure to diverse perspectives has reshaped her thinkingâ€”encouraging her to question, innovate, and explore bold ideas.

"People often think comms is just sending emails, but there's so much more to it. It's about message design, clarity, timing, what turns a message into something people actually connect with, especially in today's world where everyone's bombarded with information."
 
Working closely with senior leaders and being part of cross-functional projects has given her a holistic view of communication and valuable stakeholder management experience.
 
"There's also space to fail and figure things out. That freedom to experiment is a huge confidence booster. I've grown as a communicator, yes, but I've also grown as a professional who's learning to think bigger and push harder."

#MathCo #MathVoice

When the pandemic brought the world to a standstill in 2020, Radhika B. found an unexpected sanctuary in the quiet world of plants. What began as a way to pass the time soon became a lifeline, filling her home with greenery and her days with purpose. Initially drawn to gardening through YouTube videos, Radhika discovered more than just a hobby-she found a passion that taught her patience and resilience. 
 
Her approach to gardening is intuitive and compassionate. She believes each plant has a unique personality and needsâ€”some thrive under bright sunlight, others demand shade. She groups plants accordingly and practices â€œintentional neglectâ€â€”resisting the urge to overwater because the soil appears dry. Surprisingly, the most challenging plants for her have been succulents. Though often labeled 'low maintenance,' she found them deceptively tricky, requiring the perfect balance of well-draining soil, sunlight, and minimal watering. 
 
Despite space constraints, Radhika has created a thriving indoor oasis in her home. Her collection includes Snake Plants, Monsteras, Palms, and Ficus, while her balcony doubles as a mini vegetable garden with chilies, tomatoes, fenugreek, and mint. She experiments with unusual plants, including Mother of Thousands, a fascinating species that grows baby plantlets along its leaf edges. Sustainability is vital in her gardening philosophyâ€”she repurposes containers, composts kitchen waste, and has a special "green second chance" jar for failed plant cuttings. 
 
For Radhika, gardening is more than just growing plantsâ€”it's about slowing down and embracing nature's rhythm. "In a world obsessed with speed, gardening slows you down. It teaches you that real, lasting growth takes time, care, and a bit of faith,â€ she reflects. As she looks to the future, she hopes to deepen her understanding of soil composition, explore vertical gardening, and venture into hydroponics. For aspiring gardeners, her advice is simple yet powerful: start small. "Borrow a cutting, find a sunny windowsill, and just begin. Failure is part of the journey, but plants are more forgiving than people think," she shares.  For extra guidance, she recommends YouTube channels like "Garden Up," which played a significant role in shaping her green thumb. With every new leaf and unexpected bud, Radhika continues cultivating not just plants but also patience, joy, and a deep connection with nature.

It's World Art Dayâ€”a reminder to pause and celebrate the creativity that enriches our everyday lives. At MathCo, this creativity takes many forms, including in the thoughtful sketches of Design Associate Nikhil, whose artistic journey reveals how art can become both a personal sanctuary and a powerful form of self-expression.

Nikhil's affinity for art began during his school days as a simple pastime. "I have been sketching since my school days. What once started as a hobby eventually grew to be a form of therapy," he shares. Self-taught and driven by curiosity, Nikhil started with simple pictures and gradually progressed to exploring light, shadow, and emotion.

Nikhil's work thrives in the balance between structure and freedom. "With portraits, I like showing emotions and small details in people's faces. It feels special," he explains. "Abstract is also funâ€”there are no rules, just whatever I feel in the moment." His creative process is largely intuitive. "Sometimes I just start drawing with no plan, and slowly, an idea forms in my head. I like creating things that don't exist in real lifeâ€”but still feel like they could." Imagination leads the way, but emotions and real-life experiences shape what eventually takes form on paper.

Like many artists, he's learned to navigate the natural ebbs and flows of creativity. When inspiration wanes, he turns to rest, music, or natureâ€”allowing his creative spark to return organically. Over time, patience has become integral to his process, especially when experimenting with detailed dot work using black pens. "It takes time, but I enjoy the detail and patience it needs."

Among his works, one sketch stands outâ€”a warrior woman adorned with feathers, poised with a bow. "That sketch reminded me of the fighter in me; it wasn't plannedâ€”it just came out of how I was feeling," he reflects. For Nikhil, art is a quiet conversationâ€”between thought, feeling, and imagination. This World Art Day, we celebrate that voice and art's power to connect us with ourselves and each other.

#MathCo #HumansofMathCo #WorldArtDay

ThisÃ¢â‚¬Â¯Women's History Month, we're celebrating women who are shaping a better future for themselves and the world. Sangeetha Kannan, Project Manager at MathCo,Ã¢â‚¬Â¯is one such changemaker. Through small yet powerful choices, she champions sustainable living, proving that everyday actions can make a lasting impact.
 
"The world doesn't need a few people doing zero waste perfectly.Ã¢â‚¬Â¯What it needs isÃ¢â‚¬Â¯millions of people doing zero waste imperfectly," says Sangeetha Kannan.
 
Sangeetha is a staunch believer in this. She shares,Ã¢â‚¬Â¯"I set out trying to find small ways in which I could contribute to the betterment of the world."Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Her journey toward sustainability proves that even theÃ¢â‚¬Â¯simplestÃ¢â‚¬Â¯changes can create a ripple effect.
 
One of herÃ¢â‚¬Â¯easiestÃ¢â‚¬Â¯and most impactful shifts wasÃ¢â‚¬Â¯refusing single-use items.Ã¢â‚¬Â¯"Pledge to spend a few extra minutes every day, and you'll be well on your way to cutting down on single-use consumption,"Ã¢â‚¬Â¯she says. Waste segregation and composting wet waste at home have also been game changersÃ¢â‚¬â€small efforts that lead toÃ¢â‚¬Â¯significant environmental impact.
 
Sangeetha has incorporated severalÃ¢â‚¬Â¯eco-friendly alternativesÃ¢â‚¬Â¯into her daily routine:

Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Coconut coir & wood-based cleaning brushes
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Homemade bio enzyme cleanerÃ¢â‚¬Â¯(citrus peels + jaggery + water in a 10:3:1 ratio)
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Natural tooth powderÃ¢â‚¬Â¯in a glass jar instead of plastic toothpaste tubes
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Bamboo toothbrushesÃ¢â‚¬Â¯instead of plastic onesÃ¢â‚¬Â¯(Every toothbrush you've ever used still exists somewhere!)
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Menstrual cupsÃ¢â‚¬Â¯instead of disposable sanitary napkins
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Kajal in a tin box, used with a wooden applicator
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Wooden combs (neem/bamboo)Ã¢â‚¬Â¯instead of plastic combs
Ã¢Å“â€Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Reed diffusers with essential oilsÃ¢â‚¬Â¯instead of artificial air fresheners
 
She left us with some easy steps to reduce single-use items:

Ã¢Å“â€Carry a water bottleÃ¢â‚¬Â¯Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Refilling is an easy, sustainable choice, whether it's a short outing or a long trip.
Ã¢Å“â€Use a handkerchiefÃ¢â‚¬Â¯Ã¢â‚¬â€œ The next generation needs trees more than we need disposable tissues.
Ã¢Å“â€Keep cloth bags handyÃ¢â‚¬Â¯Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Store extras in your vehicle and always carry a few smaller ones.
Ã¢Å“â€Pack food containers & reusable cutleryÃ¢â‚¬Â¯Ã¢â‚¬â€œ A small step to avoid unnecessary packaging waste.
Ã¢Å“â€Opt for dining out instead of ordering inÃ¢â‚¬Â¯Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Enjoy your meal while cutting down on plastic packaging.
 
Sangeetha's approach is simple:Ã¢â‚¬Â¯progress over perfection.Ã¢â‚¬Â¯Let's take inspiration from her journey and commit to makingÃ¢â‚¬Â¯sustainable choices, one habit at a time.

Engineers Week Special featuring Tapas Das, Data Architect at MathCo!
 
At MathCo, our engineers don't just build systemsÃ¢â‚¬â€they solve complex problems, innovate with cutting-edge tech, and push the boundaries of data and AI.
 
We sat down withÃ‚Â TapasÃ‚Â to talk about his journey, what keeps him inspired, and his top book and game recommendations!
 
1. How did you get into engineering? Was it always the plan?
 
I got into engineering because I've always been fascinated by problem-solving and building scalable systems. Early on, I was drawn to how technology could transform raw data into meaningful insights, and that naturally led me into the world of data architecture.
 
Was it always the plan? Not exactly. While I had a strong inclination towards technology, my specific path into data engineering and architecture evolved over time. Initially, I was more focused on software development, but as I worked with large datasets and complex system designs, I realized that data engineering was where my strengths and interests aligned.
 
2. What made you choose MathCo?
 
I chose MathCo because it aligns with my passion for building scalable, high-performance data architectures and multi-cloud platforms while also providing opportunities to shape MLOps and LLMOps frameworks.
 
A few key reasons stood out are "Focus on Data & AI", "culture of innovation and technical ownership", "A Great Team & Vision".
 
3. How do you manage to game, read, and watch shows?
 
It's all about balance and priorities! Gaming is my go-to for unwinding, especially after a long workday. Currently I'm playing a story-driven game, so I plan it like a mini-seriesÃ¢â‚¬â€play for an hour or two and continue later.
 
I also keep my Kindle handy to be able to read on the go. Whenever I can squeeze in 20-30 minutes.
 
6. What's your current read? Looking for book recommendations!
 
Right now, I'm reading The Black Dahlia by James Ellroy, and it's keeping me hooked with its perfect mix of suspense, eerie atmosphere, and mind-bending twists. But I'd also recommend these 5 books for different moods and genres.
 
For a slow-burn psychological thriller, The Silent Patient by Alex Michaelides
For sci-fi and mind-bending twists, Dark Matter by Blake Crouch
For dark humor and absurdity, A Dirty Job by Christopher Moore
For layered mysteries, Magpie Murders by Anthony Horowitz
 
7. What's the best thing about being part of the MathCo engineering team?
 
A perfect blend of innovation, collaboration, and technical challenges. There's always an opportunity to experiment with the latest tools in data engineering, ML engineering, and AI-driven optimizations. The focus isn't just on delivering code, it's on building future-proof systems that drive business outcomes. Being part of the MathCo engineering team means working with brilliant minds, cutting-edge tech, and solving real-world challengesÃ¢â‚¬â€all while having the freedom to innovate, learn, and make a difference.

AI is reshaping the HR landscape.
 
AI's transformative power is undeniable, but its impact on HR is particularly game-changing. Why?
 
Daniil Mosin, Principal, MathCo, explains how HR thrives on data-driven insights to manage people, culture, and growth.
 
As organizations shift from descriptive to predictive and prescriptive analytics, HR is leveraging AI to:

Ã¢Å“â€ Enhance decision-making
Ã¢Å“â€ Optimize operations
Ã¢Å“â€ Personalize employee experiences
 
Heading into 2025, here are the top 5 AI trends shaping HR:
 
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Generative AI in talent acquisition: AI models are increasingly used to screen candidates, predict top performers and "early flight" risks, and streamline operational processes, like scheduling interviews.

Leading players see a 4x improvement in candidate conversion and a 25% reduction in time to interview via the adoption of AI tools.
 
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Predictive workforce planning: Individual-level attrition prediction and skill-based workforce demand forecasting become critical instruments of workforce planning alongside scenario modeling (e.g., hybrid vs. in-person).

For example, some of the early adopters see a 4% reduction in attrition levels via individual-level prediction and a deeper understanding of influencing factors.
 
Ã¢Å“â€¦ The proliferation of employee wellness and engagement tools: - Personalization of employee experience: AI enables hyper-personalized learning and development plans based on employee performance and individual preferences, which become ever more relevant as the technology pace accelerates.

Employee upskilling and reskilling become more frequent needs, and virtual assistants provide instant coaching and answers to HR-related queries. Additionally, advanced analytics opens opportunities to design better benefits programs based on utilization statistics and employee data.
 
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Organizational modeling and optimization enabled by advanced analytics: Companies leverage advanced analytics to design optimal organizational structures, simulate workforce scenarios, identify efficiency bottlenecks, and streamline operating models.

Mu Sigma's first Agentic AI patent dates back to 2014, when we invented a multi-agent event processing system and method that can work with real-time data.

Components of this system include:
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Core Engine - defines and deploys multi-agents to perform tasks using real-time data.
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Monitoring Engine - supervises the agents, tracking their communication, lifecycle, and processing performance.
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Computing Engine - executes the agents' assigned tasks in real-time.
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Batch Processing System - handles tasks that involve non-real-time data.
Ã¢Å“â€¦ Studio Interface - allows users to manage agents, define tasks, and oversee system operations interactively.

Our system used multi-agent coordination, improving resilience, reducing latency and increasing capability in various multi-industry use cases. We knew over a decade ago that speed was the difference between opportunity and loss and our contribution helped transform the deployment of real-time intelligence.

In a career spanning over two decades, Sagar Shah has played a pivotal role in driving digital transformation at over 25 Fortune 100 companies, establishing a proud legacy of achievements. He has led many transformative initiatives that include leading AI programs in marketing and sales analytics, Responsible AI projects, scaling next best action, vaccine hesitancy, and patient analytics, driving eCommerce, DTC, and digital initiatives, establishing Fortune 100 Centers of Excellence, and more.
 
Sagar is rooted in a philosophy likening consultants to doctors addressing patients' concerns; his approach emphasizes meticulous investigation, experimentation, and continual refinement. This guiding ethos, complemented by an unwavering dedication to ongoing learning and adaptability, has charted a diverse career trajectory - from chemical engineering and biochemistry research to venturing into digital transformations for consumer goods companies to behavioral science and machine learning in Pharma companies and beyond.
 
Sagar's core traits of curiosity, creativity, and humility serve as his guiding leadership principles, fostering an environment of proactive engagement, transparency, and professional development. Drawing inspiration from generational wisdom, he prioritizes integrity, hard work, and fearlessness in navigating professional and personal challenges.
 
Amidst the evolving landscape of the pharma industry driven by digital disruption, Sagar champions user-centric methodologies, agile prototyping, and the integration of AI as a collaborative force, all aimed at advancing healthcare outcomes for the betterment of society.

#inspiringjourneys #leadership

Hereâ€™s Shubham's throwback on the unique holiday gift he gifted his wife!
â€œAs we welcomed our baby girl into the world, I wanted to gift my wife something that truly reflected the depth of my gratitude. Thatâ€™s when I chose a pair of sustainable, lab-grown diamond earrings.

As I held our daughter in my arms, I realized no material gift could ever fully express what I felt. But I wanted to try, by choosing something intentional. Something that carried meaning.

The diamond represents the timeless strength and beauty of our love, while also aligning with my values of sustainability and purpose.

In a world where values shine as brightly as style, lab-grown diamonds are more than just stunning; theyâ€™re meaningful. Ethically created, planet-friendly, and every bit as radiant as their mined counterparts. These gems are a tribute to the modern woman: confident, conscious, and uncompromising.

When my wife opened the box, her eyes sparkled, not just with joy, but with recognition. It was a reflection of who we are and the future weâ€™re building for our daughter, rooted in mindful choices and lasting love.

For us, it became something even more:
A quiet vow.
A promise to cherish the present, honor the future, and let our values lead the way.

A bit of context:
At Fractal, we do things a little differently. Like most great companies, we love celebrating the end of an amazing year and recognizing the incredible work everyone does. This time, we got something extra special â€“ the freedom to choose our own annual holiday gift.

Some of us chose gifts for ourselves, some for our loved ones. Others saw it as a chance to support local artisans or make a difference. It wasn't just about getting a gift but about making a difference.

Stay tuned for more such stories.

Chetana Kumar is known for her leadership of Fractal's CSR initiatives from its inception. Chetana is committed to helping Fractal achieve net-zero emissions and to enhancing critical event management infrastructure.

ğŸ”¸ Insurance relies heavily on data, but it often lacks the personal touch needed to truly meet an individual's needs. That's the approach that's changing how insurance works, making it less about paperwork and more about being there when it matters most.

ğ…ğ¢ğ«ğ¬ğ­, when technical perfection gave way to business impact. The realization that perfect model metrics mean nothing if it doesn't help drive a better decision.

ğŸ”¸ Imposter syndrome often drives us to prove ourselves: longer hours, extra certifications, pushing harder. For women in tech, thereâ€™s a unique pressure to constantly validate their expertise. ğŸ”¸ The key to overcoming it? Start by acknowledging your success. Donâ€™t deflect praise; share it. Feedback from others helps break down self-doubt and build authentic confidence.
ğŸ”¸ Reach out - to leadership, a mentor, or your team. Putting yourself out there is a bold act of resilience.
ğŸ”¸ Normalizing these feelings within teams is critical. Open conversations create safe spaces. Allyship matters.

A gentle reminder: Donâ€™t be too harsh on yourself. Impostor syndrome may never fully disappear - itâ€™s part of being human, and it can even drive growth. Embrace being uncomfortable with not knowing. Thatâ€™s where transformation begins.

Hereâ€™s Shubham's throwback on the unique holiday gift he gifted his wife! 
â€œAs we welcomed our baby girl into the world, I wanted to gift my wife something that truly reflected the depth of my gratitude. Thatâ€™s when I chose a pair of sustainable, lab-grown diamond earrings.

As I held our daughter in my arms, I realized no material gift could ever fully express what I felt. But I wanted to try, by choosing something intentional. Something that carried meaning. 

The diamond represents the timeless strength and beauty of our love, while also aligning with my values of sustainability and purpose.

In a world where values shine as brightly as style, lab-grown diamonds are more than just stunning; theyâ€™re meaningful. Ethically created, planet-friendly, and every bit as radiant as their mined counterparts. These gems are a tribute to the modern woman: confident, conscious, and uncompromising.

When my wife opened the box, her eyes sparkled, not just with joy, but with recognition. It was a reflection of who we are and the future weâ€™re building for our daughter, rooted in mindful choices and lasting love.

For us, it became something even more: 
A quiet vow. 
A promise to cherish the present, honor the future, and let our values lead the way.


A bit of context: 
At Fractal, we do things a little differently. Like most great companies, we love celebrating the end of an amazing year and recognizing the incredible work everyone does. This time, we got something extra special â€“ the freedom to choose our own annual holiday gift.

Some of us chose gifts for ourselves, some for our loved ones. Others saw it as a chance to support local artisans or make a difference. It wasn't just about getting a gift but about making a difference.

In the European Union, two powerful laws are reshaping the tech sector: the AI Act and the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

â€œThereâ€™s a saying, â€˜If you never enter the water, youâ€™ll never learn how to swim.â€™ And from a very young age, Iâ€™ve always stepped into uncharted waters & figured my way through.
 
At 21, I moved abroad to fulfill my â€˜big American dreamâ€™, complete my masterâ€™s & earn in dollars. But the world there was entirely different - new people, different cultures. I had to manage it all by myself. But the only thing that kept me going was video calls with my parents.

When Fractal offered us the freedom to choose our own holiday gift this year, Khushboo saw an opportunity to give back. She chose to support Maru Ghar, a home for elderly citizens. Here's her story: 

â€œI hadnâ€™t planned anything for the holidays, but when Fractal decided to let us choose the holiday gift of our choice, something nudged me to do more. I decided to visit Maru Ghar, home to 130+ elderly residents who, despite always greeting visitors with warm smiles, often feel forgotten by society and their families. 

What struck me immediately was the incredible warmth of the place. Despite everything they've endured, the residents create a joyful family atmosphere, sharing stories and laughing together over meals. 

Talking to the wonderful people who looked after the young at heart, I was deeply moved. They spoke with so much love for the residents as if caring for their own family. Their humble, unwavering commitment was truly inspiring. 

What makes Maru Ghar so special isnâ€™t just the care they provide, but the sense of belonging they provide for those whoâ€™ve been left behind. Itâ€™s a place where every bit of support is transformed into warmth, respect, and community. 

A liâ€™l bit of context: 

At Fractal, much like most good companies, we celebrated the end of another amazing year and the incredible work everyone accomplishes through an annual holiday gift. 

This time around, all of us got to choose our own annual holiday gift. This gave us the freedom to choose it however we wanted. Some chose to gift themselves or even their loved ones, some to support local artisans, and some to use this as an opportunity to make a difference. 

Stay tuned for more such stories.

What would you do if you were gifted a small sum - enough for a five-star meal or a little shopping spree? For Nitika Goel, it became an opportunity to contribute to something much larger - Vedic Kanya High School in Gurgaon, an institution that has been quietly changing lives by educating girls from underprivileged communities since 1959. Hereâ€™s her special holiday story: 

â€œI've been inspired by Vedic Kanya High School for years now. Many girls have to walk long distances through all kinds of weather just to get to class â€“ talk about dedication! When Fractal gave us the freedom to pick our holiday gifts this year, it just clicked â€“ those sweaters and shoes we take for granted could make a big difference in their journey to a better future.
 
What really gets me about Vedic Kanya isn't just what they do, but how they've kept at it for over 60 years, believing in these girls when most didn't. They're not just educating but building future leaders in communities where education for girls isn't always valued. 

Big thanks to Fractal for letting us choose gifts that matter to us. It's pretty cool seeing how a school like Vedic Kanya keeps making waves of change decade after decade.â€

A li'l bit of context:
 
At Fractal, much like most good companies, we celebrated the end of another amazing year, and the incredible work everyone accomplishes through an annual holiday gift.

This time around, all of us got to choose our own annual holiday gift. This gave us the freedom to choose it however we wanted. Some chose to gift themselves or even their loved ones, some to support local artisans, and some to use this as an opportunity to make a difference.

As agentic AI evolves, a key challenge lies in connecting agents with enterprise systems. By default, AI agents operate in silos, limiting their potential scope and, therefore, potential use cases.

Model Context Protocol (MCP) solves this by providing an open standard for secure, consistent communication between AI models and enterprise systems.

In our latest blog post, Abhijit Guha, PhD and Amol Bandagale explain:
â¡ï¸ Why the Anthropic-proposed MCP standard is gaining momentum, with support from all the major players such as Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google, Microsoft, and OpenAI.
â¡ï¸ How MCP connects AI Agents with AI models, tools, applications and any other company resources through a simple and open architecture.
â¡ï¸ How MCP is emerging as the cornerstone of enterprise AI, enabling organizations to deploy agentic systems at scale.

â€œI still remember how excited I used to get as a kid whenever we'd pass through Pipli on our way from Bhubaneswar to Puri. This little town was like an explosion of colors and creativity that always caught my eye. Those memories came flooding back during my recent trip to Odisha.

Things have changed now. The new highway completely bypasses Pipli, and as I took a detour to visit the town, I could immediately sense something was different. The once-bustling streets seemed quieter, with fewer visitors wandering through.

I decided to explore the narrow lanes where shops displayed the famous appliquÃ© work (ornamental needlework in which pieces or patches of fabric are sewn or stuck onto a larger piece to form a picture or pattern). Each â€˜ğ˜Šğ˜©ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¥ğ˜¶ğ˜¢â€™ (traditional appliquÃ© textile) tells its own story through vibrant patterns and intricate stitching. What struck me most was how generations of craftsmanship were woven into every piece.

In one of the workshops, I noticed an elderly artisan working in peaceful silence. When he saw me admiring his creations, his face lit up with a warm smile. When I enquired about the mellow turnaround, he proudly said, moving his fingers in a rhythmic movement through the fabric, â€˜We continue to create our works of art, even if fewer come.â€™

We chatted as he worked, and I learned how the new highway had dramatically reduced foot traffic through town. Yet here he was, creating with the same passion and precision as his ancestors had for centuries.

I knew I wanted the beautiful â€˜ğ˜Šğ˜©ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¥ğ˜¶ğ˜¢â€™ showing Lord Jagannath as Krishna. The detail was breathtaking - each stitch placed with devotion and skill. This wasn't just a souvenir; it was a piece of Odisha's soul. Every stitch preserves a tradition that has been part of Odisha's identity for centuries.

Sometimes, the most meaningful connections happen when we take the road less travelled. When we slow down to appreciate the quiet dedication of people who continue creating beauty, even when the world rushes by on newer, faster roads.â€

For Sonal, the forgotten colors of Pipli were a fond memory and his cherished holiday gift! Here's his story -

"I still remember how excited I used to get as a kid whenever we'd pass through Pipli on our way from Bhubaneswar to Puri. This little town was like an explosion of colors and creativity that always caught my eye. Those memories came flooding back during my recent trip to Odisha.

Things have changed now. The new highway bypasses Pipli, and I immediately sensed something different as I took a detour to visit. The once-bustling streets seemed quieter, with fewer visitors.

In the narrow lanes, shops displayed the famous appliquÃ© work - ornamental needlework where fabric pieces form patterns. Each 'Chandua' tells its story through vibrant patterns and intricate stitching, with generations of craftsmanship woven into every piece.

In one workshop, an elderly artisan worked in peaceful silence. When he saw me admiring his creations, his face lit up. When I asked about the quiet atmosphere, he proudly said while moving his fingers rhythmically through fabric, 'We continue to create our works of art, even if fewer come.'

The new highway had reduced foot traffic, yet he created with the same passion as his ancestors had for centuries.

I chose a beautiful 'Chandua' showing Lord Jagannath as Krishna. The detail was breathtaking - each stitch placed with devotion and skill. This wasn't just a souvenir; it was a piece of Odisha's soul, preserving a tradition central to its identity.

Sometimes, the most meaningful connections happen when we take the road less travelled and appreciate the quiet dedication of people who continue creating beauty, even when the world rushes by on newer, faster roads."

Here's Rashmi Tiwari's throwback on the unique holiday gift she gifted herself!

"I was just walking by a small display near the mall when something caught my eye. Wow, handmade carpets! Each one was so colorful and had these amazing patterns that I couldn't look away. Right then and there, I knew I wanted to gift myself something special.

The shop was run by Hasib uncle, a super sweet elderly man who was excited to show me around. He told me how he learned carpet-making from his parents and how each piece has its own story. He helped me find the perfect carpet - one with these earthy and elegant designs that just felt right.
As we chatted, I learned something cool. Hasib uncle wasn't just selling carpets. He was using this work to support his nieces' education. How amazing is that? By continuing this traditional craft, he was helping his family build a better future.

This whole experience was pretty special. I only wish I had clicked a picture with him to remember this.

Thanks to fractal.ai giving us the freedom to choose our own holiday gifts, I didn't just buy a carpet. I connected with a story, supported a local artisan, and found something that means something to me."

A bit of context :
At Fractal, we do things a little differently. Like most great companies, we love celebrating the end of an amazing year and recognizing the incredible work everyone does. This time, we got something extra special Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the freedom to choose our own annual holiday gift.

Some of us chose gifts for ourselves, some for our loved ones. Others saw it as a chance to support local artisans or make a difference. It wasn't just about getting a gift but about making a difference.

Stay tuned for more such stories.
hashtag#HolidayGifts hashtag#Culture

We had the opportunity to participate in the India-Scotland Business Meet 2025, organized by the Consulate General of India, Edinburgh, alongside FICCI, Scottish Development International, Grant Thornton, and Scottish commerce bodies. Held at the City Chambers in Edinburgh on March 5, the event brought together esteemed leaders, including Lord Provost of Edinburgh Councillor Robert Aldridge, Deputy First Minister Kate Forbes, FICCI Council Chair Priya Guha, and Consul General Siddharth Malik. The discussions focused on strengthening India-Scotland economic ties, fostering strategic partnerships, and driving trade and investment in key sectors.

4 years later, my manager asked if IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d like to go to the US for a project. But I didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t even have a passport. He encouraged me, & in 2016, I boarded my 1st flight to the US. I instantly fell in love with the work culture, the lifestyle & the people. So in 2017, I moved my family to Chicago.

It was a transformative time - not just for my career but for my life. I climbed the work ladder, led global projects for Fractal, & solved impossible challenges. But my proudest moment wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t any of that. It was standing in the house I bought for my dad - a real home, something weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d only dreamed of. I looked around & thought, Ã¢â‚¬ËœIf only Mom could see this.Ã¢â‚¬â„¢

Today, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m the Customer Success Lead at FractalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Chicago office - a far cry from where I began. And if a boy from the slums of Mumbai can make it this far, I believe anyone can. Because the thing about dreams is, with hard work, they become a reality!

AI is no longer an application. Itâ€™s becoming the infrastructure of progress.
This message was clear at NVIDIAâ€™s GTC in DC, where every discussion focused on how industries are rebuilding around data, compute, and efficiency.

Here are the 5 industry forward viewpoints shared by our business head, Parijat Banerjee, who attended the event:

- Finance: AI is moving beyond automation into collaboration. Federated learning is enabling leading banks to train shared fraud models without exchanging sensitive data, cutting detection times from days to minutes.
- Healthcare: AI is helping doctors and nurses reclaim time by automating tasks and enabling ambient listening to focus on patients. Eli Lilly and SchrÃ¶dinger are using digital twins to accelerate trials and lower costs.
- Industry and Energy: Companies like NVIDIA, Foxconn, and Schneider are designing â€œAI factoriesâ€ that blend compute, robotics, and power. 
- Science and Space: NVIDIA and the US Department of Energy are building seven national AI supercomputers to accelerate breakthroughs in quantum, materials, and biopharma. 
A key vision: Nobel Prizeâ€“worthy research in hours rather than decades within the next decade.
- Technology: The focus is shifting from experimentation to efficiency â€” cloud, cost, and compute. 

But amid all the promise, one reminder stood out: AI is good with 80%, but struggles with the 20% â€” human judgment, empathy, and context.
The next phase of growth will belong to those who teach their systems to learn responsibly with data that is contextual, collaborative, and inclusive.
Compute is the new steel. Data is the new currency. The future of intelligence must stay human-centered.

Weâ€™re excited to see how these shifts reshape industries.

Your supply chain faces an unexpected disruptionâ€”how do you respond?

A few years ago, companies were relying on predictive analyticsâ€”basically trying to predict the future. However, prescriptive analytics takes it a step further, allowing businesses to not only foresee problems but also uncover hidden patterns and take real-time action.

Sunder Balakrishnan, our Practice Head â€“ Supply Chain, shares three key ways prescriptive analytics strengthens supply chain resilience. 

Here's how it's changing the game.

"What happened" is just half the story, to get the full picture you need to ask "why".
